body: That's a bug, it's trying the non-print function grammar first. @JelleZijlstra :-)

issue.title: Try no-print grammar first in Python 2

body:
@ambv @JelleZijlstra 
Hello. Sorry, but I am still facing this bug under python 3.
Can we get a release out for this? Trying to use the current release on 2.x is producing ugly code with these extra spaces.

issue.title: New Release To Fix 2.7
issue.body:
This is a redux #977 because I had some craziness going on in my paths.

The current release of `black` is 19.3b0 and it has a number of issues that affect 2.x code.  These include:

- https://github.com/psf/black/issues/768: `Cannot parse: 3:19: print('hello', file=sys.stdout)`
- https://github.com/psf/black/issues/752: ugly whitespace `print (something)`

Both issues are pretty terrible for code trying to be 2.x/3.x compatible, and both issues have been fixed in `master`. However, neither are part of a current release.  

Can we get a new release out? If not, could we at least get a bugfix release out (19.3b1) that includes those two fixes?

issue.title: Format code with Black

labels.name: needs rebase or merge

milestone.title: The Blackening
milestone.description: There's a long story, and lots of discussion about adopting black for pip's codebase. This milestone is a dump for making it easier to understand the history by putting it all in a single place.

issue.body:
<!---
Thank you for your soon to be pull request. Before you submit this, please
double check to make sure that you've added a news file fragment. In pip we
generate our NEWS.rst from multiple news fragment files, and all pull requests
require either a news file fragment or a marker to indicate they don't require
one.

To read more about adding a news file fragment for your PR, please check out
our documentation at: https://pip.pypa.io/en/latest/development/contributing/#news-entries
-->

Continuation of https://github.com/pypa/pip/pull/5425.

Adds Black config in `pyproject.toml`:
* Exclude `_vendor` dir
* No other options, uses Black's defaults

Update isort config in `setup.cfg` for compatibility with Black:
* Requires the new isort option `ensure_newline_before_comments` so isort plays nicely with Black
* It's not been released yet, so update `.pre-commit-config.yaml` to use the latest isort develop branch SHA for the time being
* Black issue: https://github.com/psf/black/issues/251
* isort PR: https://github.com/timothycrosley/isort/pull/1000

issue.title: Switch to GitHub Actions for CI
issue.body:
### Motivation for changes:
Try out github actions as a replacement for circleci
Hopefully we don't need to maintain custom docker images this way

#### To Do:

- [ ] Get it working
- [ ] Verify we like it better than circleci
- [ ] Add a release workflow

body:
Has this been switched to the stable branch? I am (per the vim instructions) using the latest stable version of black and I still hit this issue. I commented here: https://github.com/psf/black/issues/988

It seems like the commit should be there: https://github.com/psf/black/commit/d6db1c12a8e14833fe22da377cddc2bd1f43dc14

However I am hitting this issue today (june 2020) with the latest stable black while editing python 2.7 code using `let g:black_target_version=27` in vimrc

Facing this issue with Python 3.6 
Black formats this piece of code `print("cacheops.{} for {}".format(event, sender))` to `print ("cacheops.{} for {}".format(event, sender))` 
And then the flake8 checker flags this under E211
I vote to reopen this issue. I do not think this is closed or resolved.

Ran into this on V 19.10b0. Looks like the spaces after the `print ()` are added if there is a print statement (`print "test"`) in the code. Totally my mistake but thought it might save others some hair.
